trans-unit.source: Using the Azure CLI with Azure Storage | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Using the Azure CLI with Azure Storage | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI) with Azure Storage to create and manage storage accounts and work with Azure blobs and files.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI) with Azure Storage to create and manage storage accounts and work with Azure blobs and files.

trans-unit.source: Using the Azure CLI with Azure Storage
trans-unit.target: Using the Azure CLI with Azure Storage

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: The Azure CLI provides a set of open source, cross-platform commands for working with the Azure Platform.
trans-unit.target: The Azure CLI provides a set of open source, cross-platform commands for working with the Azure Platform.

trans-unit.source: It provides much of the same functionality found in the Azure Management Portal as well as rich data access functionality.
trans-unit.target: It provides much of the same functionality found in the Azure Management Portal as well as rich data access functionality.

trans-unit.source: In this guide, we’ll explore how to use [Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI)](../xplat-cli.md) to perform a variety of development and administration tasks with Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: In this guide, we’ll explore how to use [Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI)](../xplat-cli.md) to perform a variety of development and administration tasks with Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you download and install or upgrade to the latest Azure CLI before using this guide.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you download and install or upgrade to the latest Azure CLI before using this guide.

trans-unit.source: This guide assumes that you understand the basic concepts of Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: This guide assumes that you understand the basic concepts of Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: The guide provides a number of scripts to demonstrate the usage of the Azure CLI with Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: The guide provides a number of scripts to demonstrate the usage of the Azure CLI with Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to update the script variables based on your configuration before running each script.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to update the script variables based on your configuration before running each script.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The guide provides the Azure CLI command and script examples running in Azure Service Management mode (ASM).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The guide provides the Azure CLI command and script examples running in Azure Service Management mode (ASM).

trans-unit.source: See [Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows with Azure Resource Management](../azure-cli-arm-commands.md#azure-storage-commands-to-manage-your-storage-objects) for Azure CLI commands for storage in Azure Resource Management (ARM) mode.
trans-unit.target: See [Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows with Azure Resource Management](../azure-cli-arm-commands.md#azure-storage-commands-to-manage-your-storage-objects) for Azure CLI commands for storage in Azure Resource Management (ARM) mode.

trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Storage and the Azure CLI in 5 minutes
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Storage and the Azure CLI in 5 minutes

trans-unit.source: This guide uses Ubuntu for examples, but other OS platforms should perform similarly.
trans-unit.target: This guide uses Ubuntu for examples, but other OS platforms should perform similarly.

trans-unit.source: **New to Azure:** Get a Microsoft Azure subscription and a Microsoft account associated with that subscription.
trans-unit.target: **New to Azure:** Get a Microsoft Azure subscription and a Microsoft account associated with that subscription.

trans-unit.source: For information on Azure purchase options, see [Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/), [Purchase Options](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/purchase-options/), and [Member Offers](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/member-offers/) (for members of MSDN, Microsoft Partner Network, and BizSpark, and other Microsoft programs).
trans-unit.target: For information on Azure purchase options, see [Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/), [Purchase Options](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/purchase-options/), and [Member Offers](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/member-offers/) (for members of MSDN, Microsoft Partner Network, and BizSpark, and other Microsoft programs).

trans-unit.source: See [Manage Accounts, Subscriptions, and Administrative Roles](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/hh531793.aspx) for more information about Azure subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: See [Manage Accounts, Subscriptions, and Administrative Roles](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/hh531793.aspx) for more information about Azure subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: After creating a Microsoft Azure subscription and account:
trans-unit.target: After creating a Microsoft Azure subscription and account:

trans-unit.source: Download and install the Azure CLI following the instructions outlined in [Install the Azure CLI](../xplat-cli-install.md).
trans-unit.target: Download and install the Azure CLI following the instructions outlined in [Install the Azure CLI](../xplat-cli-install.md).

trans-unit.source: Once the Azure CLI has been installed, you will be able to use the azure command from your command-line interface (Bash, Terminal, Command prompt) to access the Azure CLI commands.
trans-unit.target: Once the Azure CLI has been installed, you will be able to use the azure command from your command-line interface (Bash, Terminal, Command prompt) to access the Azure CLI commands.

trans-unit.source: Type `azure` command and you should see the following output.
trans-unit.target: Type `azure` command and you should see the following output.

trans-unit.source: Azure Command Output
trans-unit.target: Azure Command Output

trans-unit.source: In the command line interface, type `azure storage` to list out all the azure storage commands and get a first impression of the functionalities the Azure CLI provides.
trans-unit.target: In the command line interface, type `azure storage` to list out all the azure storage commands and get a first impression of the functionalities the Azure CLI provides.

trans-unit.source: You can type command name with **-h** parameter (for example, `azure storage share create -h`) to see details of command syntax.
trans-unit.target: You can type command name with **-h** parameter (for example, `azure storage share create -h`) to see details of command syntax.

trans-unit.source: Now, we’ll give you a simple script that shows basic Azure CLI commands to access Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Now, we’ll give you a simple script that shows basic Azure CLI commands to access Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: The script will first ask you to set two variables for your storage account and key.
trans-unit.target: The script will first ask you to set two variables for your storage account and key.

trans-unit.source: Then, the script will create a new container in this new storage account and upload an existing image file (blob) to that container.
trans-unit.target: Then, the script will create a new container in this new storage account and upload an existing image file (blob) to that container.

trans-unit.source: After the script lists all blobs in that container, it will download the image file to the destination directory which exists on the local computer.
trans-unit.target: After the script lists all blobs in that container, it will download the image file to the destination directory which exists on the local computer.

trans-unit.source: In your local computer, open your preferred text editor (vim for example).
trans-unit.target: In your local computer, open your preferred text editor (vim for example).

trans-unit.source: Type the above script into your text editor.
trans-unit.target: Type the above script into your text editor.

trans-unit.source: Now, you need to update the script variables based on your configuration settings.
trans-unit.target: Now, you need to update the script variables based on your configuration settings.

trans-unit.source: **<storage_account_name>** Use the given name in the script or enter a new name for your storage account.
trans-unit.target: **<storage_account_name>** Use the given name in the script or enter a new name for your storage account.

trans-unit.source: **Important:** The name of the storage account must be unique in Azure.
trans-unit.target: **Important:** The name of the storage account must be unique in Azure.

trans-unit.source: It must be lowercase, too!
trans-unit.target: It must be lowercase, too!

trans-unit.source: **<storage_account_key>** The access key of your storage account.
trans-unit.target: **<storage_account_key>** The access key of your storage account.

trans-unit.source: **<container_name>** Use the given name in the script or enter a new name for your container.
trans-unit.target: **<container_name>** Use the given name in the script or enter a new name for your container.

trans-unit.source: **<image_to_upload>** Enter a path to a picture on your local computer, such as: "~/images/HelloWorld.png".
trans-unit.target: **<image_to_upload>** Enter a path to a picture on your local computer, such as: "~/images/HelloWorld.png".

trans-unit.source: **<destination_folder>** Enter a path to a local directory to store files downloaded from Azure Storage, such as: “~/downloadImages”.
trans-unit.target: **<destination_folder>** Enter a path to a local directory to store files downloaded from Azure Storage, such as: “~/downloadImages”.

trans-unit.source: After you’ve updated the necessary variables in vim, press key combinations “Esc, : , wq!”
trans-unit.target: After you’ve updated the necessary variables in vim, press key combinations “Esc, : , wq!”

trans-unit.source: to save the script.
trans-unit.target: to save the script.

trans-unit.source: To run this script, simply type the script file name in the bash console.
trans-unit.target: To run this script, simply type the script file name in the bash console.

trans-unit.source: After this script runs, you should have a local destination folder that includes the downloaded image file.
trans-unit.target: After this script runs, you should have a local destination folder that includes the downloaded image file.

trans-unit.source: The following screenshot shows an example output:
trans-unit.target: The following screenshot shows an example output:

trans-unit.source: After the script runs, you should have a local destination folder that includes the downloaded image file.
trans-unit.target: After the script runs, you should have a local destination folder that includes the downloaded image file.

trans-unit.source: Manage storage accounts with the Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: Manage storage accounts with the Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: Connect to your Azure subscription
trans-unit.target: Connect to your Azure subscription

trans-unit.source: While most of the storage commands will work without an Azure subscription, we recommend you to connect to your subscription from the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: While most of the storage commands will work without an Azure subscription, we recommend you to connect to your subscription from the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: To configure the Azure CLI to work with your subscription, follow the steps in [How to connect to your Azure subscription](../xplat-cli.md#how-to-connect-to-your-azure-subscription).
trans-unit.target: To configure the Azure CLI to work with your subscription, follow the steps in [How to connect to your Azure subscription](../xplat-cli.md#how-to-connect-to-your-azure-subscription).

trans-unit.source: Create a new storage account
trans-unit.target: Create a new storage account

trans-unit.source: To use Azure storage, you will need a storage account.
trans-unit.target: To use Azure storage, you will need a storage account.

trans-unit.source: You can create a new Azure storage account after you have configured your computer to connect to your subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can create a new Azure storage account after you have configured your computer to connect to your subscription.

trans-unit.source: The name of your storage account must be between 3 and 24 characters in length and use numbers and lower-case letters only.
trans-unit.target: The name of your storage account must be between 3 and 24 characters in length and use numbers and lower-case letters only.

trans-unit.source: Set a default Azure storage account in environment variables
trans-unit.target: Set a default Azure storage account in environment variables

trans-unit.source: You can have multiple storage accounts in your subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can have multiple storage accounts in your subscription.

trans-unit.source: You can choose one of them and set it in the environment variables for all the storage commands in the same session.
trans-unit.target: You can choose one of them and set it in the environment variables for all the storage commands in the same session.

trans-unit.source: This enables you to run the Azure CLI storage commands without specifying the storage account and key explicitly.
trans-unit.target: This enables you to run the Azure CLI storage commands without specifying the storage account and key explicitly.

trans-unit.source: Another way to set a default storage account is using connection string.
trans-unit.target: Another way to set a default storage account is using connection string.

trans-unit.source: Firstly get the connection string by command:
trans-unit.target: Firstly get the connection string by command:

trans-unit.source: Then copy the output connection string and set it to environment variable:
trans-unit.target: Then copy the output connection string and set it to environment variable:

trans-unit.source: Create and manage blobs
trans-unit.target: Create and manage blobs

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob storage is a service for storing large amounts of unstructured data, such as text or binary data, that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via HTTP or HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob storage is a service for storing large amounts of unstructured data, such as text or binary data, that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via HTTP or HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: This section assumes that you are already familiar with the Azure Blob storage concepts.
trans-unit.target: This section assumes that you are already familiar with the Azure Blob storage concepts.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information, see [How to use Blob Storage from .NET](storage-dotnet-how-to-use-blobs.md) and [Blob Service Concepts](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd179376.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For detailed information, see [How to use Blob Storage from .NET](storage-dotnet-how-to-use-blobs.md) and [Blob Service Concepts](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd179376.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Create a container
trans-unit.target: Create a container

trans-unit.source: Every blob in Azure storage must be in a container.
trans-unit.target: Every blob in Azure storage must be in a container.

trans-unit.source: You can create a private container using the `azure storage container create` command:
trans-unit.target: You can create a private container using the `azure storage container create` command:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] There are three levels of anonymous read access: **Off**, **Blob**, and **Container**.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] There are three levels of anonymous read access: **Off**, **Blob**, and **Container**.

trans-unit.source: To prevent anonymous access to blobs, set the Permission parameter to **Off**.
trans-unit.target: To prevent anonymous access to blobs, set the Permission parameter to **Off**.

trans-unit.source: By default, the new container is private and can be accessed only by the account owner.
trans-unit.target: By default, the new container is private and can be accessed only by the account owner.

trans-unit.source: To allow anonymous public read access to blob resources, but not to container metadata or to the list of blobs in the container, set the Permission parameter to **Blob**.
trans-unit.target: To allow anonymous public read access to blob resources, but not to container metadata or to the list of blobs in the container, set the Permission parameter to **Blob**.

trans-unit.source: To allow full public read access to blob resources, container metadata, and the list of blobs in the container, set the Permission parameter to **Container**.
trans-unit.target: To allow full public read access to blob resources, container metadata, and the list of blobs in the container, set the Permission parameter to **Container**.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Manage Access to Azure Storage Resources](storage-manage-access-to-resources.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Manage Access to Azure Storage Resources](storage-manage-access-to-resources.md).

trans-unit.source: Upload a blob into a container
trans-unit.target: Upload a blob into a container

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob Storage supports block blobs and page blobs.
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob Storage supports block blobs and page blobs.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Understanding Block Blobs and Page Blobs](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee691964.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Understanding Block Blobs and Page Blobs](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee691964.aspx).

trans-unit.source: To upload blobs in to a container, you can use the `azure storage blob upload`.
trans-unit.target: To upload blobs in to a container, you can use the `azure storage blob upload`.

trans-unit.source: By default, this command uploads the local files to a block blob.
trans-unit.target: By default, this command uploads the local files to a block blob.

trans-unit.source: To specify the type for the blob, you can use the `--blobtype` parameter.
trans-unit.target: To specify the type for the blob, you can use the `--blobtype` parameter.

trans-unit.source: Download blobs from a container
trans-unit.target: Download blobs from a container

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to download blobs from a container.
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to download blobs from a container.

trans-unit.source: Copy blobs
trans-unit.target: Copy blobs

trans-unit.source: You can copy blobs within or across storage accounts and regions asynchronously.
trans-unit.target: You can copy blobs within or across storage accounts and regions asynchronously.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to copy blobs from one storage account to another.
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to copy blobs from one storage account to another.

trans-unit.source: In this sample we create a container where blobs are publicly, anonymously accessible.
trans-unit.target: In this sample we create a container where blobs are publicly, anonymously accessible.

trans-unit.source: This sample performs an asynchronous copy.
trans-unit.target: This sample performs an asynchronous copy.

trans-unit.source: You can monitor the status of each copy operation by running the `azure storage blob copy show` operation.
trans-unit.target: You can monitor the status of each copy operation by running the `azure storage blob copy show` operation.

trans-unit.source: Note that the source URL provided for the copy operation must either be publicly accessible, or include a SAS (shared access signature) token.
trans-unit.target: Note that the source URL provided for the copy operation must either be publicly accessible, or include a SAS (shared access signature) token.

trans-unit.source: Delete a blob
trans-unit.target: Delete a blob

trans-unit.source: To delete a blob, use the below command:
trans-unit.target: To delete a blob, use the below command:

trans-unit.source: Create and manage file shares
trans-unit.target: Create and manage file shares

trans-unit.source: Azure File storage offers shared storage for applications using the standard SMB 2.1 protocol.
trans-unit.target: Azure File storage offers shared storage for applications using the standard SMB 2.1 protocol.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure virtual machines and cloud services can share file data across application components via mounted shares.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure virtual machines and cloud services can share file data across application components via mounted shares.

trans-unit.source: You can manage file shares and file data via the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: You can manage file shares and file data via the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: For more information on Azure File storage, see [How to use Azure File storage with PowerShell and .NET](storage-dotnet-how-to-use-files).
trans-unit.target: For more information on Azure File storage, see [How to use Azure File storage with PowerShell and .NET](storage-dotnet-how-to-use-files).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure File storage is currently in preview.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure File storage is currently in preview.

trans-unit.source: To request access to the preview, navigate to the [Microsoft Azure Preview page](/services/preview/), and request access to **Azure Files**.
trans-unit.target: To request access to the preview, navigate to the [Microsoft Azure Preview page](/services/preview/), and request access to **Azure Files**.

trans-unit.source: Once your request is approved, you'll be notified that you can access the File storage preview.
trans-unit.target: Once your request is approved, you'll be notified that you can access the File storage preview.

trans-unit.source: You can then create a storage account for accessing File storage.
trans-unit.target: You can then create a storage account for accessing File storage.

trans-unit.source: Create a file share
trans-unit.target: Create a file share

trans-unit.source: An Azure File share is an SMB 2.1 file share in Azure.
trans-unit.target: An Azure File share is an SMB 2.1 file share in Azure.

trans-unit.source: All directories and files must be created in a file share.
trans-unit.target: All directories and files must be created in a file share.

trans-unit.source: An account can contain an unlimited number of shares, and a share can store an unlimited number of files, up to the capacity limits of the storage account.
trans-unit.target: An account can contain an unlimited number of shares, and a share can store an unlimited number of files, up to the capacity limits of the storage account.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a file share named **myshare**.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a file share named **myshare**.

trans-unit.source: Create a directory
trans-unit.target: Create a directory

trans-unit.source: A directory provides an optional hierarchical structure for an Azure file share.
trans-unit.target: A directory provides an optional hierarchical structure for an Azure file share.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a directory named **myDir** in the file share.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a directory named **myDir** in the file share.

trans-unit.source: Note that directory path can include multiple levels, *e.g.*, **a/b**.
trans-unit.target: Note that directory path can include multiple levels, *e.g.*, **a/b**.

trans-unit.source: However, you must ensure that all parent directories exists.
trans-unit.target: However, you must ensure that all parent directories exists.

trans-unit.source: For example, for path **a/b**, you must create directory **a** first, then create directory **b**.
trans-unit.target: For example, for path **a/b**, you must create directory **a** first, then create directory **b**.

trans-unit.source: Upload a local file to directory
trans-unit.target: Upload a local file to directory

trans-unit.source: The following example uploads a file from **~/temp/samplefile.txt** to the **myDir** directory.
trans-unit.target: The following example uploads a file from **~/temp/samplefile.txt** to the **myDir** directory.

trans-unit.source: Edit the file path so that it points to a valid file on your local machine:
trans-unit.target: Edit the file path so that it points to a valid file on your local machine:

trans-unit.source: Note that a file in the share can be up to 1 TB in size.
trans-unit.target: Note that a file in the share can be up to 1 TB in size.

trans-unit.source: List the files in the share root or directory
trans-unit.target: List the files in the share root or directory

trans-unit.source: You can list the files and subdirectories in a share root or a directory using the following command:
trans-unit.target: You can list the files and subdirectories in a share root or a directory using the following command:

trans-unit.source: Note that the directory name is optional for the listing operation.
trans-unit.target: Note that the directory name is optional for the listing operation.

trans-unit.source: If omitted, the command lists the contents of the root directory of the share.
trans-unit.target: If omitted, the command lists the contents of the root directory of the share.

trans-unit.target: Copy files

trans-unit.source: Beginning with version 0.9.8 of Azure CLI, you can copy a file to another file, a file to a blob, or a blob to a file.
trans-unit.target: Beginning with version 0.9.8 of Azure CLI, you can copy a file to another file, a file to a blob, or a blob to a file.

trans-unit.target: Below we demonstrate how to perform these copy operations using CLI commands.
